_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


ENTERPRISE OPERATING PRODUCTS - MONT BELVIEU FACILITY
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At the Enterprise Products Mont Belvieu Facility, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Mont Belvieu Complex that are regulated by EPA's RMP rule including isobutene and methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE).  The processes involved include fractionation, reaction, separation, and distillation.  Enterprise utilizes gas-fired turbines to generate electricity or run compressors, and to supply heat for process operations.  Additionally, there are a number of gas-fried heaters to provide heat for various processes including distillation.  The facility utilizes three flares: south flare (for the south complex), LRGO flare (for the Splitter I, West Terminal and Dow), and north flare (for MTBE and Splitter II).

In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

Chlorine is used in the regeneration process of the oleflex catalyst and is consumed in that portion of the MTBE unit.

Ammonia is used as a reagent treating the MTBE unit turbine exhaust in the SCR packing.  Ammonia is stored in a coded pressure vessel and is contained in a clos

ed loop system until it is consumed in the SCR process in the heat recovery unit.

Flammables

Propane is a finished product at the Mont Belvieu facility.  A portion of this production comes from the Propylene Splitter units, as well as the NGL Fractionators.  The quantity of this product is distributed throughout the complex.

Propylene is a finished product.  All of this production line is derived from the two propylene Splitter units.  The quantity is distributed between the unit production and the Storage Well.

Isobutane is produced in the Butamer units of which there are two running in parallel.  This is done by converting normal butane into isobutene.

Normal Butane is the feed to the Butamer units.  Most normal butane is pipelined directly into the Butamer unit and is converted to isobutene.

Mixed butanes are produced from the NGL Fractionators and Butamer units and are fed to De-Isobutanizers, which separate the isobutene and normal butane.

Our accidental release prevention program and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.


KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  This data is in the RMP data field of the report.

This information is used  to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Enterprise Products takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  The Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanic

al integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - PSSR
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As a part of the prevention efforts, there are a multitude of programs in which Enterprise employees participate.  A training program has been developed in which the Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the plant, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.

The Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

ACCIDENT HISTORY

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

On June 23, 2003, a hydrocarbon release and fire occurred in the Seminole Unit, which is in the Fractionator process, while maintenance activities were underway.  The ethane (C2) pump discharge valve was being replaced in the unit, and the unit was on total reflux at the time of the release.  However, the process line was not liquid-free and de-pressured due to a check valve of which the operators were unaware.  A hose blew off causing the release and immediate fire.  One operator was injured during the incident.  This incident was subjected to a formal incident investigation process to identify and correct the root ca

use of the event.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Mutual Aid Mont Belvieu group, which includes the Mont Belvieu Police, fire department, and Emergency Medical Service as well as the Chambers County Emergency Management system.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

* The PSM system is constantly being subjected to critical reviews with an objective of improving the programs.
* The written PSM management system has completed a comprehensive, thorough review, with specific emphasis being placed on the written mechanical integrity program.
* The Emergency Preparedness Plan update and reviewed was completed in June of 2004.  Training on the updates are scheduled for the fall of this year.
* The Safety Procedures and Policies Manual was reviewed and updated in February of 2003.
